tossups.question: A woman in this novel spends all her time writing letters for charities in Africa but ignores the fact that her child's head is stuck in a banister. This novel begins with a description of so much mud that one might see a Megalosaurus and “Fog everywhere.” A character in this novel who “honors” others by letting them pay his bills is named Mr. Skimpole. George Henry Lewes complained about the death of rag-and-bottle merchant Krook by (*) spontaneous combustion in this novel. Lady Dedlock goes undercover as her maid in order to discover that this novel’s narrator is her daughter. Richard Carstone and Ada Clare marry and receive an inheritance, but find that the legal fees for disputing it have spent it all. For 10 points, name this novel narrated by Esther Summerson about the Jarndyce v. Jarndyce Chancery court case, by Charles Dickens.

This country’s merchants invented horseshoe-shaped bracelets of bronze or copper known as okpoho for trading purposes. This country used large cross-like objects called padroes to claim territory. One conquest by this country was supported by Pope Nicholas V in the Bull Dum Diversas. This country’s missionaries supported a local ruler against a syncretic religion inspired by Saint Anthony of Padua. This country opposed the Antonianism of Kimpa Vita and had earlier converted Nzinga a Nkuwu to Christianity. This country, which dominated the (*) Kongo Kingdom for centuries, launched a successful surprise attack on Ceuta under King John I and established a school for explorers at Sagres. An explorer from this country was the first European to sail around the Cape of Good Hope. For 10 points, name this home country of Bartolomeu Dias.

Rashi suggested that the four messengers received by this person each expired upon completing his mission, while Nachmanides claimed the messengers were all suffering delusions. The Talmudic tractate Baba Bathra debates whether and when this figure existed, with various Rabbis suggesting this person was contemporaneous with Moses, the Babylonian exiles, or Esther. The Vilna Gaon addresses that Talmudic debate by calling this person not a (*) parable but a mashal, or role model. This man says that he will die naked, just as he was born, and that “I know my Redeemer lives.” Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar try to convince this man that his present state is the result of his sins. For 10 points, name this Biblical character who helps God win a bet with Satan by retaining his faith despite numerous trials.
tossups.answer: Job [or Iyov; accept “Book of Job” until “this person”]

tossups.question: One work in A major for this instrument was based on a Lutheran hymn “Aus tiefer Not”; that work is part of Felix Mendelssohn’s set of six sonatas for this instrument. Fanny Mendelssohn’s only work for this instrument is Prelude in F Major, which she composed for her own wedding. Another set of works composed for this instrument was dedicated to Charles-Valentin Alkan and was designed to show off the capabilities of a new Cavaille-Coll designed instrument (*) acquired by the composer. An F major concerto for this instrument is nicknamed The Cuckoo and the Nightingale, and J.S. Bach supposedly walked over 400km to Lubeck to listen to Dietrich Buxtehude play this instrument. Charles Barker developed the first pneumatic lever for this instrument in Church of St. Sulpice. For 10 points, name this keyboard instrument connected to large pipes.

This author vituperated against a parent who taught his child to chainsmoke in a criticism of the “casual family” in his newspaper column. One of this man’s narrators claims he will “go on living to sixty!...To seventy! To eighty!” before describing his vocation as “the intentional pouring of water through a sieve.” A monologue by a Mephistopheles-quoting pawnbroker pacing around the body of his wife, whom he drove to suicide, makes up this author’s story (*) “A Gentle Creature.” One of this man’s narrators sarcastically praises a glutton drinking toasts to “the sublime and the beautiful” and asserts that there is enjoyment even in a toothache. That narrator sobs, “They won’t let me - I can’t be good!” to the prostitute Liza and begins his recollections, “I am a sick man. I am a spiteful man.” For 10 points, name this author of Notes from the Underground.

Bourgoin attempted to catalogue this ancient art form, whose girih form is broken into sections by lines.  Kashi is a traditional form of this art, as opposed to another form that uses a plaster base and was known as zellige. In an example of this art form, the text of a prayer in gold against a (*) blue background runs around a building’s interior. Eight-pointed stars were a common motif in these things, which decorate the Comares Palace and the walls around the fountain in the Court of the Lions. The Alhambra and the Dome of the Rock feature Islamic examples of this art form, in which, since they didn’t feature human images, plant-like patterns and geometric tessellations were common. For 10 points, name this art form created by putting together small tiles to form an image.

This political party outlined its views in a 27 point manifesto that was later revised to 26 points. This party savaged the SEPU department store in its daily Arriba newspaper. One leader of this party became known as “the Missing One” after he was executed for alleged treason. The “Old Shirts” faction of this party was led by Manuel Hedilla. This party forced everyone to join a union called the (*) Vertical Syndicate despite its previous support for Syndicalism. Two leaders of this party were buried within the Santa Cruz Basilica at the Valley of the Fallen. This party led the efforts to oust the government of Manuel Azana, for which it received the assistance of the Condor Legion. This party was founded by Jose Primo de Rivera and later led a civil war against the Republicans after subsuming the Carlists. For 10 points, name this Spanish Fascist party led by Francisco Franco.
tossups.answer: Falange [or Spanish Phalanx of the Councils of the National-Syndicalist Offensive; Falange Espanola Tradicionalista de las Juntas de Ofensiva Nacional-Sindicalista; FE-JONS; FET-JONS]
tossups.answer_formatted: Falange [or Spanish Phalanx of the Councils of the National-Syndicalist Offensive; Falange Espanola Tradicionalista de las Juntas de Ofensiva Nacional-Sindicalista; FE-JONS; FET-JONS]
acceptable: Spanish Phalanx of the Councils of the National-Syndicalist Offensive

tossups.question: In 2014, Srivastava et. al introduced the idea of randomly removing components of these devices to improve their performance, a technique known as dropout. Some of these devices involve passing a filter over various parts of the input, and others have internal directed cycles which function as memory. Those are the convolutional and recurrent types of these devices, respectively. The McCulloch-Pitts model provided the inspiration for these devices, and they are the subject of an algorithm that (*) iteratively uses the chain rule to compute a loss, the backpropagation algorithm. These devices consist of layers of hidden units stacked in between an input and output layer, with an activation function between each layer. For 10 points each, name these computational models often used in deep learning, named for their similarity to the structure of the human brain.

A politician from this state befriended Vladimir Putin over an arm wrestling contest while employed as one of Ronald Reagan’s speechwriters. That congressman from this state reportedly tried to arrange a presidential pardon for Julian Assange in exchange for proof that Russia did not hack Hillary Clinton’s emails. Before Jason Chaffetz assumed the job, the chairman of the House Oversight Committee was a congressman from this state. That congressman, the former CEO of Directed Electronics, is the (*) wealthiest currently serving member of Congress. Russia apologist Dana Rohrabacher hails from this state, as does a congressman who succeeded Eric Cantor as House Majority Leader. Republicans Darrell Issa and Kevin McCarthy are from, for 10 points, what state that is mostly represented in Congress by Democrats, such as Kamala Harris.

Transport due to these entities is modelled by Peierls solution to the Boltzmann transport equation, which uses the relaxation time approximation. Klemens and Callaway name models for scattering due to these entities. Scattering of these entities in an inelastic manner increases thermal resistivity at high temperatures and is known as umklapp. For a basis of two atoms in the primitive cell, the type of these entities with a nonzero frequency at the center of the first Brillouin zone is known as their (*) optical type. Multiplying the density of states of these entities by their energy, integrating up to their cutoff frequency, and differentiating gives a temperature-cubed dependence of heat capacity at low temperatures in the Debye model. For 10 points, name these quasiparticles which correspond to the vibrational modes of a lattice.

A talking one of these animals was the child of Demeter while she was disguised as a Fury, although its twin Despoine was a normal goddess. Polydectes offered Perseus the task of killing Medusa as an alternative to bringing him one of these animals. After taking the form of this animal, Boreas fathered twelve of them which could run across a field of grain without crushing it; these animals were also often associated with the (*) winds in general. Abderus is killed by some of these animals, which are defeated by being scared onto a peninsula which is cut off into an island. Hector’s epithet refers to his taming of these animals. In his eighth labor, Heracles had to capture some of these animals owned by Diomedes. For 10 points, name this animal, which formed the bottom half of a centaur in Greek mythology.
tossups.answer: horse [accept mares or stallions or synonyms for “horse”]

tossups.question: California senator William Knowland was nicknamed for his opposition to this country. John Service led the Dixie Mission to establish relations with the future leaders of this country. Unsuccessful opposition to this country resulted in the scapegoating of Owen Lattimore. Experts on it were dubbed “[this country] Hands.” The first Western journalist to interview the future leaders of this country was Edgar Snow. A White Paper summarizing American relations with it was written by (*) Dean Acheson. In order to oppose the rise of this country, former US Army Chief of Staff George Marshall was appointed Special Envoy to it. The United States did not establish official relations with this country until 1972. President Truman was widely derided for “losing” this country. For 10 points, name this country which became Communist in 1949 after a civil war won by Mao Zedong.
tossups.answer: China [do NOT accept or prompt on “Taiwan”]

tossups.question: Note to players: the answer to this tossup is a function, like sine or the gamma function, but not those. One equation involving this function modifies another equation by including steric effects of substituents. This function of reaction rate plotted against this function of the equilibrium constant for a series of acids gives a line according to the Bronsted catalysis equation. Chemical potential is equal to k times (*) T times this function of fugacity, and Gibbs free energy is equal to negative R times T times this function of the equilibrium constant. An expression involving this function is set equal to sigma times rho in the Hammett equation. This function is applied to a ratio of molarities in the Henderson-Hasselbach equation. For 10 points, name this function that when applied to the concentration of hydrogen ions gives the negative pH.
tossups.answer: logarithm [accept ln or natural logarithm or base ten logarithm]

tossups.question: This thinker compared an “American flirtation in which it is understood from the beginning that nothing is to happen” to the impoverished life that results from lack of risk or stakes. This thinker claimed that the original sin must have been a patricide against the “God Father,” and that organic life has an “urge” to restore an earlier, inorganic state of things. This author argued that we wish the death of strangers but are ambivalent towards those we love in “Reflections on War and Death,” and that war strips away the pretense of our (*) civilized attitude toward death. After seeing the trauma of veterans from the first World War, this psychologist wrote about how Thanatos, the death drive, conflicts with Eros, the life drive in Beyond the Pleasure Principle. For 10 points, name this psychoanalyst who wrote The Interpretation of Dreams.

With Sasaki and Ubeda, this scientist proposed the idea of “pacemaker islands” that restore genetic diversity in models of host-parasite evolution. This scientist used the life table of Taiwanese people to show how the forces of natural selection scale over age in one article. This scientist posited that secondary sexual ornamentation is a signal of disease and parasite resistance with Marlene Zuk. One result named for this scientist is usually formulated as “C is less than r times B”, where r is the (*) coefficient of relatedness. That result, first published in “The genetical evolution of social behavior”, was summarized by J. B. S. Haldane as he’d die for two brothers or eight cousins. For 10 points, name this evolutionary biologist whose namesake rule is used to quantify kin selection.

This substance titles the third volume of The Venture of Islam, where Marshall Hodgson argued that this substance was vital to the creation of “military patronage states”—a hypothesis he articulated with William McNeill. The invention of this substance is legendarily attributed to a German called Berthold Schwarz. William of Rubruck may have brought this substance to Europe, since it appears in the Opus Majus of Roger Bacon. The three Islamic empires (*) based on this substance were the Mughals, Safavids, and Ottomans. An early formula for this substance incorporated birthwort herb. This substance, whose original name means “fire medicine,” helped end feudal society in Europe. For 10 points, Taoist alchemists likely used saltpeter and sulfur to create what explosive substance?
tossups.answer: gunpowder [or black powder; huoyao; accept fire medicine before mention; prompt on “saltpeter”]
tossups.answer_formatted: gunpowder [or black powder; huoyao; accept fire medicine before mention; prompt on saltpeter]

tossups.question: One architect from this place published books like The Small Home of Tomorrow to provide plans for middle-class families. Because white clients didn’t want to sit next to a black man, that architect learned to draft entire drawings upside down. He also designed a structure consisting of four sweeping concrete arches around a central tower. A famous building in this city features a huge central area with a skylight surrounded by wrought-iron stairs and (*) exposed elevators. This home of Paul Williams is also home to a binoculars-shaped building and another building that was sanded down due to its extreme heat and glare. The Googie style became popular in this city, which features a famous building with many concave stainless steel panels. For 10 points, name this city of the Bradbury Building and the Walt Disney concert hall, designed by Frank Gehry.
tossups.answer: Los Angeles [or L. A.; prompt on “California” or “America” before “this city”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Los Angeles [or L. A.; prompt on California or America” before “this city]

tossups.question: One character from this city refers to a woman as “the machine gun” because her spit flies when she talks and makes fun of her sister for singing operatically about her love for a man she sees out the window. Another character from this city is dismayed to find his mother is marrying a much younger baker; his son Ridwan later joins a group of ambitious gay politicians. One character from this city disappoints his family by becoming a Marxist journalist and marrying a coworker. That character’s father rejects his wife after a (*) car hits her and breaks her collarbone, and he calls his son an atheist for publishing an article on Darwin; that man is Al-Sayyid Ahmad. This city names a series about Fahmy, Yasin, and Kamal which includes the novels Sugar Street and Palace Walk. For 10 points, name this city which names a Trilogy by Naguib Mahfouz.

This man tested his ability to extemporize on a theme by describing a sunset in one memoir. In one essay, this man criticized Vladimir Propp’s folktale classification system as vague and lacking context; he ended that essay by proposing that “languages exist in which an entire myth can be expressed in a single word.” This man wrote “I hate (*) traveling and travelers” in a work analysing the Bororo people of Brazil. This man contrasted bricoleurs, who are bound by the materials they have, with engineers, who have the “true scientific mind.” This author of Tristes Tropiques created a “culinary triangle” and stated that heating food marks the transition from savagery to civilization in his “The Raw and the Cooked.” For 10 points, name this French author of The Savage Mind and Mythologiques, the founder of structural anthropology.

A character in this play introduces himself as a “permanent transient,” and is described as “not poorly dressed, but carelessly.” It’s neither Hamlet nor based on Hamlet, but two characters in it argue about the differences between “north,” “due north,” and “northerly.” A man in this play calls himself a “h-o-m-o-s-e-x-u-a-l” and says, “We neither love nor hurt because we do not try to reach each other” and asks, “Was trying to feed the (*) dog an act of love?” while musing on his attempts to kill his landlady’s dog with poisoned meat. One of the characters in this play repeats “Oh my god” while the other asks “Could I have planned all this?” after impaling himself on a knife. For 10 points, name this play about Peter and Jerry that takes place around a bench in Central Park, the first play by Edward Albee.
tossups.answer: The Zoo Story [accept “Edward Albee’s At Home at the Zoo” or “Peter & Jerry” until “first play”) Bonuses:
tossups.answer_formatted: The Zoo Story [accept “Edward Albee’s At Home at the Zoo” or “Peter & Jerry” until “first play”) Bonuses:
acceptable: The Zoo Story [accept “Edward Albee’s At Home at the Zoo” or “Peter & Jerry” until “first play”) Bonuses:
Zoo Story [accept “Edward Albee’s At Home at the Zoo” or “Peter & Jerry” until “first play”) Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: Hurricane Harvey will likely be the second costliest hurricane in United States history after Katrina. For 10 points each:
parts: This televangelist was broadly criticized for not immediately opening the doors of the Lakewood megachurch in the wake of Harvey. He later told victims of the hurricane to not have a “poor me” mentality.
Another hurricane that had a large financial cost due to its proximity to a major city rather than its strength was this 2012 “Frankenstorm,” which flooded New York City streets and subway lines.

A tanker filled with this type of compound caught fire in Crosby, Texas. This type of compound is capped on both ends with clusters of carbon and can be used in plastics as a source of radicals during chain polymerization.

bonuses.leadin: This poem represents a place where “Reason’s self shall bow the knee / To shadows and delusions.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem, which contrasts the dead in a sleeping posture with a corpse placed so that he seems to be “seated with his friends.” It describes a “restless … queen” and a “shade” of “the hunter and the deer.”
“The Indian Burying Ground,” along with “The British Prison-Ship” and “The Wild Honeysuckle,” were written by this “Poet of the American Revolution.”

Philip Freneau was hired as an anti-Federalist journalist by this man. William Wells Brown’s novel Clotel; or, The President’s Daughter fictionalized the life of this man’s daughter by his slave Sally Hemmings.

bonuses.leadin: This song begins with the lyrics “sitting by the roadside on a summer’s day/ chatting with my messmates, passing time away.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this hit song of the 1860s, rivaled only by “Dixie” in its popularity with Southern soldiers. Its title refers to the boiled peanuts famished Southerners were forced to eat during the war.

Julia Ward Howe’s “Battle Hymn of the Republic” borrowed its tune from a Union army marching song about this man’s “Body.” This abolitionist led an 1859 raid on Harpers Ferry and committed the Pottawatomie massacre.

Edmund Wilson’s Patriotic Gore is named after a song about this state, sung to the tune of “O Tannenbaum.” It references the attack of Union troops moving through this state by Confederate sympathizers in the Pratt Street riot.

bonuses.leadin: This limit is described weirdly often for touch as “dropping the wing of a bee onto your cheek from a distance of 1 centimeter” and for smell as “one drop of perfume in a six-room house.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this concept from psychophysics, defined as the lowest limit of a sensory stimulus that an organism can detect.

Absolute threshold is contrasted with difference threshold, which is quantified by this law later extended by Fechner’s Law. It states that the noticeable difference between two stimuli is a constant ratio of the original stimulus.
Weber’s law can be quantified by asking subjects to measure these objects. In Asch’s conformity experiments, subjects “went along” with obviously wrong comparisons of these objects’ length.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the history of tofu. For 10 points each:
parts: Liu Bei’s sworn brother Guan Yu was supposedly a tofu seller in his early life. This other brother of Liu Bei wielded a “serpent spear” and was assassinated when his subordinates defected to Sun Quan’s army.

Tofu may be the “cheese” mentioned in the journals of John Saris, who met with this Asian leader. This leader was advised by the English sailor William Adams, or the Pilot of Miura, and he signed a Christian Expulsion Edict.

One story claims that tofu was invented by a prince of this dynasty since his parents were old and couldn’t chew soybeans anymore. This dynasty names the dominant ethnic group of China and succeeded the Qin dynasty.

bonuses.leadin: This artist created his own images inspired by Pictures at an Exhibition, including a geometric day-night scene for The Great Gate of Kiev and a Morse-code Baba Yaga. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this expressionist painter of many abstract “compositions” who connected painting to music in Concerning the Spiritual in Art. He is also known for co-founding The Blue Rider.

Kandinsky used this musical name for works that were more spontaneous than compositions. The study for his 8th shows a man holding a large sword, and 31 shows blue and green sails of ships in a sea battle.

This other founding member of The Blue Rider had an affair with Kandinsky. Her Meditation depicts a pensive woman by a stained-glass window, and she picked up Fauvist influences in works like The Yellow House.

bonuses.leadin: This author’s most recent essay collection is based on advice given to her friend on how to raise a baby girl as a feminist. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of Dear Ijeawele who wrote about the relationship of Ifemelu and Obinze in Americanah. Her story “Birdsong” describes a woman remembering her unhappy affair with a married man while waiting in traffic.
Adichie is from this country, also home to Ben Okri and Chinua Achebe.

In this Adichie short story, an extension of Things Fall Apart, Nwamgba sends her son to a missionary school. The story flashes forward to her granddaughter Grace, who is inspired to change her name to Afamefuna.

bonuses.leadin: The cubic phase of zirconium tungstate exhibits this property. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property, which also occurs in some invar alloys. This property will occur if the third derivative of the interatomic potential is positive.

The thermal expansion coefficient is divided by the constant-pressure or constant-volume type of this quantity in the formula for the Grüneisen parameter. It is defined as the amount of heat needed for a 1K temperature change.

The adiabatic or isothermal varieties of this quantity appear in the numerator of the Grüneisen parameter. It is proportional to the negative derivative of pressure with respect to volume, and its inverse gives the compressibility.

bonuses.leadin: Solely because the question writer is hungry right now, name some things about food in Norse mythology. For 10 points each:
parts: In Valhalla, this boar-like creature is roasted in the cauldron Eldhrimnir every night and eaten by all the warriors before returning to life. According to the Poetic Edda, its meat is the “best of bacons.”
The wisdom-giving mead of poetry was created when Fjalar and Galar killed this wise man and mixed his blood with honey. He was created from the saliva of the Aesir and Vanir.
This trickster god lost a contest to eat through a trough of meat to the middle because his opponent was fire and ate through the trough as well.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about epistasis in genetics, for 10 points each:
answers: synthetic lethal [prompt on partial, accept word forms]
parts: Traits that are epistatic to another are often inherited in this fashion, in which two copies of an allele are needed to express the trait. These alleles are usually written in lowercase, and are contrasted with dominant alleles.

In a dihybrid cross between two double heterozygotes, with one recessive trait epistatic to the other, this is the ratio of phenotypes obtained. I’m looking for a series of 3 or 4 numbers, in any order.
In this type of epistatic interaction, complete knockout of two genes results in death, but knockout of one gene or the other is viable.

bonuses.leadin: Thomas Paine and Adam Smith are among the people who helped administer this measure. For 10 points each:
answers: Hundred Years’ War [or Second Hundred Years’ War]
parts: Name this measure that John Brewer argues allowed Britain to develop a “fiscal-military” state in his book Sinews of Power. This measure overtook a similar one on land and helped Britain fund its extraordinary war debts.

The excise tax helped Britain win the second of these conflicts against France, which lasted from 1689 to 1815. Henry V won the Battle of Agincourt during the first conflict of this name, which also lasted a very long time.

Brewer claims that the Treasury became more professional under this monarch’s officials Sidney Godolphin and Robert Harley. Sarah Churchill was a confidant of this ruler, whose reign saw the Scottish Act of Union.

bonuses.leadin: Nelson Goodman’s “companionship” and “imperfect opportunity” objections to this work center on its explanation of “similarity circles.” For 10 points each:
answers: The Logical Structure of the World [or Der Logische Aufbau der Welt]
parts: Name this 1928 work in five parts that aimed to develop “constitution theory,” a new philosophical discipline that would synthesize recent science and the work of Frege and Russell.
The Logical Structure of the World is by this German philosopher, who argued in Pseudoproblems in Philosophy that many “classic” metaphysical questions were more sophistry than philosophy.
Carnap was part of this group of philosophers that also included Otto Neurath, Karl Menger, and Moritz Schlick. It met at a namesake university in Austria.
answers_formatted: The Logical Structure of the World [or Der Logische Aufbau der Welt]
acceptable: The Logical Structure of the World

bonuses.leadin: Mixing two equivalents of a reagent containing this element with copper (I) iodide creates a Gilman reagent. For 10 points each:
answers: -78 Celsius [don’t forget about the negative there]
parts: Name this element that’s present in a type of carbon nucleophile reagent that’s stronger than a Grignard reagent. It’s n-butyl form is a commonly used strong base.
Adding an organolithium reagent to a carbonyl compound creates this functional group. They have a PKa around 16 to 19 and add to alkyl halides to form ethers.
Gilman reagents are commonly prepared at this temperature, which is the temperature at which dry ice sublimes. Answer in Celsius to the nearest whole number, please.
answers_formatted: -78 Celsius [don’t forget about the negative there]

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about female figures in Buddhism, for 10 points each:
parts: Maya, the mother of Siddhartha Gautama, saw a white one of these animals in a dream on the night that she conceived her child. In the dream it entered her side, and it supposedly emerged as a human ten months later.

This deity swore to be reborn as a female until samsara was achieved when some douchebag told her that she could only be enlightened after she was reincarnated as a male. This tantric deity is most commonly depicted in her green form.
Tara is prominent in the Vajryana Buddhism of this region. The Dalai Lama should be ruling from this region but is currently in exile.

bonuses.leadin: In this play, a girl and her lover, who is disguised as a music master, sing a duet about shepherds which is a thinly veiled description of the play’s actual plot. For 10 points each:
answers: The Imaginary Invalid [or Le Malade Imaginaire]
fakes his own death [accept reasonable synonyms, prompt on “hiding” or “spying” since he does those things as well]
parts: Name this play in which Angelique marries Cleante despite being promised to a doctor by her hypochondriac father Argan.
The Imaginary Invalid was written by this 17th-century French author of comedies such as The Misanthrope and Tartuffe.
The maid Toinette and Argan’s brother Beralde get Argan to do this to find that his wife Beline does not actually love him. He later does this to trick Angelique and Cleante.
answers_formatted: fakes his own death [accept reasonable synonyms, prompt on “hiding or spying” since he does those things as well]

bonuses.leadin: Brahms’s first work of this type is sometimes nicknamed after the lied “Rain Song,” upon which he based the third movement. For 10 points each:
answers: multiple stops [Accept double stops, triple stops, or quadruple stops]
parts: Name this type of work, the ninth of which Beethoven rededicated to Kreutzer after he had a fight with George Bridgetower. Bach paired these works with Partitas in a well-known set of six works.

Perhaps the most cherished section of Sonatas and Partitas for Solo Violin is this final movement of the second partita, which Yehudi Mehunin praised as “the greatest structure for solo violin that exists.” Brahms wrote a left-hand only transcription of this movement for piano.
Many notes in Sonatas and Partitas call for this technique, leading Emil Temanyi to create his controversial 1954 recording using a Vega bow.
answers_formatted: multiple stops [Accept double stops, triple stops, or quadruple stops]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about some beautiful gardens. For 10 points each:
parts: Salomon de Caus built the Hortus Palatinus garden in this city with a water organ and a statue of Memnon for Frederick the Winter King. This capital of the Palatinate was mostly destroyed during the 30 Years’ War.

The gardens of this friend of Augustus were built on the Esquiline Hill and allegedly contained the first heated swimming pool in Rome. Virgil’s Georgics were written to honor this patron of poets and writers like Horace.
This city’s Boboli gardens contain a Fountain of Neptune and statues of “Abundance.” That garden in this city was built behind the Pitti palace by Cosimo de Medici for his wife, Eleanora of Toledo.

bonuses.leadin: This poem ends with an exhortation to “Love virtue, she alone is free.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this masque, in which the “Lady” is captured by the title character, who traps her to a chair and tries to offer her a drink. She is freed by the Attendant Spirit and the water nymph Sabrina.
Comus was written by this poet who “justif[ied] the ways of God to man” in Paradise Lost.

An “uncouth swain” says “I come to pluck your berries harsh and crude” in this eulogy to his drowned friend Edward King. It commands “Look homeward, Angel” and “O ye dolphins, waft the hapless youth.”

bonuses.leadin: Computers have a hard time understanding languages. For 10 points each:
parts: One common problem in natural language processing is the problem of doing this thing to a sentence, and thus visualizing its syntactic structure in the namesake diagram.

Parsing and other NLP tasks can often be performed using these models, which assume that there is a set of unobserved states and attempt to determine transition and emission probabilities for these states.

One of the great success of NLP was this program, which learned to understand Jeopardy clues and eventually proved better than the best human players. Whether it could beat you at Penn Bowl is still unknown.

bonuses.leadin: In an aria, this character stresses the word “hang” while singing the line “when I appear the people hang on my words.” For 10 points each:
answers: Chiang Ch’ing [or Madame Mao; Jiang Qing; accept descriptive answers like “the wife of Mao Zedong”; do not accept or prompt on “Mao”]
Richard “Dick” Milhouse Nixon [prompt on “Tricky Dick” or facetious equivalents]
parts: Name this character who repeatedly shrieks “I speak according to the book” in an aria delivered after the wife of a visiting dignitary interrupts a performance of The Red Detachment of Women.
Chiang Ch’ing sings the aria “I am the wife of Mao Zedong” in Act II of John Adams’ opera about this American president’s 1973 state visit to China.

The role of Madame Mao is considered to be this kind of soprano part, characterized by high-pitched and technically difficult arias. The Queen of the Night in Mozart’s The Magic Flute is played by this kind of soprano.
answers_formatted: Chiang Ch’ing [or Madame Mao; Jiang Qing; accept descriptive answers like “the wife of Mao Zedong; do not accept or prompt on "Mao"]
Richard “Dick” Milhouse Nixon [prompt on Tricky Dick or facetious equivalents]
acceptable: descriptive answers like “the wife of Mao Zedong
